newsitem.title: USA: Dow powers past 8,000 after earnings, price data.
newsitem.headline: Dow powers past 8,000 after earnings, price data.

text.p: The Dow Jones Industrial Average shattered the 8,000 mark on Wednesday after strong corporate profits and mild inflation data combined to trigger a buying frenzy.
The Dow finished up 63 points, or 0.79 percent, at 8039, taking just over five months to rise from the 7,000 level passed on February 13.
Technology stocks extended their torrid run, driving the Nasdaq composite to its biggest single-day point rise. It jumped 38.5 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1581.
The Nasdaq index's previous largest point rise came on May 2, when it gained 34.83.
Record closing highs were set across all major U.S. stock indices, including the Dow, the Nasdaq composite, the Standard & Poor's 500 and the New York Stock Exchange composite.

"It's a powerhouse day for the stock market in general," said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. "The Dow is the focus, but it's really the junior stocks and the tech stocks that have done so well."
The Dow's gain came despite a sharp selloff in one of its 30 component stocks, Eastman Kodak Co.
Kodak fell 8-3/4 points to 68-1/8 after it reported second-quarter earnings well below Wall Street analysts' forecasts. The drop was the equivalent of over 32 Dow points.
Still, disappointment over Kodak's results was offset by strong earnings elsewhere and further evidence that there are no signs of accelerating inflation in the U.S. economy.
The Labor Department reported the June Consumer Price Index, a gauge of inflation at the retail level, rose 0.1 percent. Wall Street economists had expected the CPI to rise 0.2 percent.

"Inflation continues to be tame...and profits seem to be really good," said Arun Kumar, senior U.S. equities strategist at Lehman Brothers. "So it's a very good recipe for the stock market to perform very well."

Underpinning the rise by stocks was a sharp drop in long-term interest rates after the inflation data. The 30-year bond was up 28/32 in late trading, its yield falling to 6.48 percent, dipping below the key 6.50 percent level.
Stronger-than-expected earnings announced late Tuesday by semiconductor maker Intel Corp provided the catalyst for the huge rally in technology shares.
Intel surged 7-15/32 to 88-3/8. Microsoft Corp, due to report earnings Thursday, rocketed 9-31/32 to 148-7/32. Compaq Computer Corp rose 6-1/4 to 133-1/2 and Sun Microsystems Inc rose 3-7/16 to 45.
The frenzied buying, particularily in the technology group, had some analysts questioning whether Wall Street stocks had gone too far, too fast.

"It's got all the markings of a blow-off rally," said Bob Walberg, chief equity strategist at Briefing.Com, an online market research and analysis firm. "There's just no regard for valuations in this marketplace."

ITT Corp rose 4-5/16 to 66-15/12 after saying it will split into three separate companies to fend off a $6.5 billion takeover bid from rival Hilton Hotels Corp. ITT said also announced a share buyback program.
Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp fell 4-12/16 to 34-3/16. It said some of its facilities had been served with with federal search warrants requesting hospital laboratory billing and homecare documents.
Lucent Technologies Inc gained 5-15/16 to 88-11/16 after it reported that its third-quarter earnings tripled to $0.33 a share, up from $0.11 in the year-earlier period.

Time Warner Inc reported a second-quarter loss of $0.09, versus a loss of $0.28 in the 1996 quarter and compared with analysts' consensus expectation of a loss of $0.14. Its shares rose 4-1/4 to 49-5/8.

Ford Motor Co reported the highest quarterly profit in U.S. corporate history, $2.53 billion, while General Motors Corp overcame two strikes to post stronger-than-expected earnings for the second quarter. Ford ended off 1-1/2 to 40-5/8, and GM rose 1/8 to 54-3/8.
The S&P 500 index rose 10.83 points to 936.59, a record.
The Nasdaq Composite rose 38.52 to 1580.63, a record.
((-- Wall Street desk, 212-859-1730))
